If you go work in someone's laboratory and they tell you what research to do and what experiments to carry out, then the work does mostly belong to the originator  of the idea. It may have been Mangold's dissertation, but it was Spemann's Thesis.
Jocelyn Bell discovered pulsars, but her accomplishments too were stolen from her by her male advisor, Anthony Hewish, and he got the Nobel for it.
Yet another example of old white men taking credit for the work of those they deem less then or unworthy of credit for their own contributions.

Kind of a small detail, but the notocord and neural tube definitions are mixed up around 2:50. The notocord is a precursor to the spine while the neural tube is what actually develops in to the spinal cord itself.

The Matilda Effect is a bias against acknowledging the achievements of those women scientists whose work is attributed to their male colleagues.

The biggest damn problem with the Nobel Prizes is that they aren't awarded posthumously. How many other individuals are largely lost to history? Discounted simply because they died before their important contribution was properly recognised - by the Nobel Committee, or not...

That they've also conspicuously failed to recognise the important contributions of many women, while noting men within identical fields (even co-workers!), has also been something of a scandal. (Although this has improved significantly in recent years, there still is a long way to go.)

You are implying, without coming out and saying, that Mangold was somehow gyped in the the credit department because she was a woman. Judging from some of the comments, many of your viewers have got that impression. However, you do not present a case for this.

In science the #1 person gets the credit, the prizes and the historical acclaim most of the time. When their work is mentioned in textbooks, it is only the supervisor who is mentioned. The applies to male supervisors and female graduate students, as well as female supervisors and male graduate students. (Jennifer Doudna and Emmanuelle Charpentier won the 2020 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for their work on CRISPR; the male and female members of their research groups, who performed the experiments, did not, and nobody knows their names.) You are, in other words, lying about your subject and misleading your viewers in the interests of gender politics. When you do things like that you bring science into disrepute.

The way you put it sounds like it was okay to only give Spemann the Nobel Prize because he was the only one involved in the discovery still alive, right? Right? Wrong. The reason why Spemann and Mangold performed their experiments in the first place was because another woman had pioneered in the field 10 years earlier. She had done work with hydras (small water animals), and her discoveries were pretty groundbreaking and already hinted at the Spemann-Mangold-Organiser, just in a different animal.
She was still alive when Spemann got his Nobel, and she should've shared the prize with him.

As for her name: I can't keep it in mind. I think her first name was Gretel or Gretchen, but not sure.
